questions.text: A 55-year-old man has been in the ICU for the past 1 month due to end-stage liver failure. He is not eligible for a transplant and his doctors have said there is nothing they can do at this stage. His family has consented to organ donation once his heart stops. Which of the categories of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified Maastricht classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would fall under category III. 

Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors:

  • Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared
    • Category I - includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene and resuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).
    • Category II - donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophes who are brought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who die in the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, and stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission.
    • Category V - Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care.
  • Controlled - transplant team present and prepared
    • Category III - encompasses patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are the patients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatment and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.
    • Category IV - comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the determination of brain death.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen of a 75-year-old woman shows the following findings. Which Bosniak class does the cyst belong to?
questions.solution:
The presence of a simple renal cyst without any septations, calcifications, or enhancing soft tissue components is classified as Bosniak class I. They do not require treatment or follow-up imaging.

Bosniak classification:

Depending on the CT characteristics the renal cysts are classified mainly into four classes:

Class I: It is a simple benign cyst, without any septations.

Class II: The cyst consists of one or more thin (<1 mm) septa running through them. Class II lesions are benign.

The subcategory class IIF includes lesions with multiple class II features, large hyperdense cysts (>3cm), or hyperdense cysts that are totally intrarenal. These cysts are more complex and do not fit into categories II or III. They require follow-up for up to 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III: These are complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification. The walls of the cyst or septae show enhancement. The class III lesions should be surgically explored or biopsied. <50% will turn out to be malignant.

Class IV: These are malignant lesions with solid enhancing nodules. Surgical removal to be considered.

questions.text: Which is the classification system used for the fracture shown in the x-ray given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of the fracture of the proximal humerus. The most widely accepted classification is the Neer classification, which involves 4 major segments in injuries:

  • Head of humerus
  • Greater tuberosity
  • Lesser tuberosity
  • Shaft of humerus

Neer classiﬁcation distinguishes between the number of displaced fragments, with displacement deﬁned as greater than 45 degrees of angulation or 1 cm of separation.

Other options

Option A: The Schatzker classification is a method of classifying tibial plateau fractures.

Option B: The Ideberg classification is a method of classification of intra-articular glenoid fossa fractures.

Option D: The Gartland classification is a method of classification of supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

questions.text: A pet shop owner presented with upper abdominal discomfort. On examination, mild tenderness is found in the right hypochondrium. USG revealed a cyst with the finding given in the image below. According to WHO classification, this cyst belongs to which of the following type?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG showing a cyst with detached membranes(Water Lily sign) are suggestive of a hydatid cyst. Cyst with detached membranes is classified as CE-3 according to the WHO classification. 

WHO classification of hydatid cyst

Stage

 Description

CL (cystic lesion)

Unilocular anechoic cystic lesion without internal echoes or septations

CE (cystic echinococcosis) 1

Uniformly anechoic cyst with fine internal echoes that represent protoscolices after rupturing of a vesicle, called ‘hydatid sand’

CE 2

Cyst with internal septation representing the walls of the daughter cyst described as multivesicular, honeycomb, cartwheel, or rosette formation

CE 3
(transitional stage) description of daughter cyst

3A: daughter cysts with detached laminated membrane(Water lily sign)

3B- daughter cysts inside a solid matrix

CE 4(inactive/degenerative)

Daughter cysts can no longer be seen.

A mixture of hypoechoic and hyperechoic features – like a bag of wool

CE 5

(inactive/degenerative)

  

Calcification of the wall; either partial or complete

Hydatid Cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species(dog tapeworm ). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. Diagnosis is suggested by the finding of a multiloculated cyst on ultrasound and is further supported by the finding of a floating membrane within the cysts on a CT scan. Active cysts contain a large number of smaller daughter cysts (multi-vesicular rosette-like cystic lesions with daughter cysts) which is characteristic of hydatid cysts of the liver.

The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below)

The serpent sign is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst, on CT imaging.

A ball of wool sign is seen on ultrasound when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst, as seen below.

The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.

questions.text: A male baby weighing 1.6 kg, born at 34 weeks, has abdominal distension and hematochezia on the 16th day of life. He is apneic, bradycardic, and lethargic. He was fed only with artificial formula milk. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a portal vein gas shadow. What is the stage of disease according to modified Bell's staging criteria?
questions.solution:
Abdominal distension and hematochezia in a preterm baby exclusively fed on formula feed are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The abdominal x-ray finding of portal vein gas shadow is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB, according to modified Bell's staging criteria.

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal x-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

The given x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

questions.text: Todani classification system is used for the assessment of _______.
questions.solution:
Todani classification is used for the assessment of Choledochal cysts.

Other options:

Option C: Milwaukee classification is used to assess the sphincter of Oddi dysfunction.

Option D: Strasberg classification is used in bile duct injuries. It is based on the anatomical location of the injury.

Feature

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. Which part of the aorta is involved in this condition?
  1. Ascending aorta
  2. Arch of aorta
  3. Descending aorta
questions.solution:
The part of the aorta involved in the above clinical scenario, i.e. Stanford type B aortic dissection, is the descending aorta.

Aortic dissection most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

It is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimomedial flap.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Clinically, patients present with tearing chest/back pain associated with diaphoresis, syncope, weakness, and dyspnea or neurological manifestations.

On examination, unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. There can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary edema. 

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double lumen aorta. 

The image below shows aortic dissection in the thoracic aorta with the true lumen, as well as the false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented with a history of trivial fall while climbing the stairs. She has pain in the right hip and is unable to walk. An X-ray was performed and is shown below. Which of the following is not a classification system for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of a fracture of the neck of femur. Gartland classification is used for supra-condylar fracture of the humerus.

Classifications of fracture neck of femur: 

  • Garden classification: It is based on the degree of displacement of the fracture.

 

  • Pauwels classification: It is based on the angle of inclination of the fracture with respect to the horizontal plane.

 Anatomical classification

  • Subcapital – a fracture just below the head;
  • Transcervical – a fracture in the middle of the neck
  • Basal – a fracture at the base of the neck

Fractured neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors). 

A plain radiograph may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of the femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line (as shown in the image below)

Clinical features of a fractured neck of femur include painful movements of the hip joint, shortening and external rotation of the affected limb, and tenderness in the hip. Active straight leg raising is not possible

Complications include non-union and avascular necrosis of the femoral head. 

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

Related Pearl: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus 
  • Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Intra-articular fractures

questions.text:
Match the following columns:
Surgery/wound Expected infection rate 
1. Elective hernia repair a. 1.5%
2. Elective colorectal surgery b. 2.4%
3. Elective cholecystectomy c. 10.2%
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B-1-a, 2-c, 3-b.

There is no need to remember the actual percentage values. Wounds have to be arranged in increasing order of infection rates. Surgical wounds are classified based on the expected amount of bacterial load at the time of surgery. 

Class I surgical wounds are clean wounds. They are noninfected surgical wounds without any inflammation.

Examples:

  • Hernia repair
  • Breast biopsy specimen

Class II surgical wounds are clean/contaminated wounds. They are surgical wounds that include an entry hollow viscus such as the respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract under controlled conditions without significant spillage. Examples:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgery (not colon) 
  • Elective colorectal surgeries have a higher rate of infection among class-II wounds. 

Class III surgical wounds are contaminated wounds. They include fresh open accidental wounds, surgeries with a major break in sterile technique, gross spillage of the gastrointestinal tract, or incision through an inflamed nonpurulent tissue.

Examples:

  • Open cardiac massage
  • Penetrating abdominal trauma

Class IV surgical wounds are dirty wounds. They are old traumatic wounds with the presence of necrotic tissue and perforated viscus with a heavy load of contamination.

Examples:

  • Perforated diverticulitis
  • Necrotizing soft tissue infection

Wound Class, representative procedures, and expected infection rates

WOUND CLASS

EXAMPLES OF CASES

EXPECTED INFECTION RATES

Breast biopsy

1–2%

2.1–9.5%

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: As per Sade classification, what is the grade assigned to atelectasis of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The term atelectasis is used to define the tympanic membrane touching the promontory. This is classified as grade 3 by Sade classification.

  • Pars Tensa retraction is graded using Sade grading
  • Pars flaccida retraction is graded using Tos grading

Sade’s classification of retraction of pars tensa:

  • Grade 1 – Mild retraction not touching the long process of the incus 
  • Grade 2 – Retracted drum touching the long process of the incus
  • Grade 3 – Touching promontory but mobile on segalization—atelectasis of the middle ear
  • Grade 4 – Plastered to promontory (immobile)—adhesive middle ear

Tos’ classification of retraction of pars flaccida:

  • Grade 1 – Mild attic retraction not touching the neck of the malleus.
  • Grade 2 – Touching neck of the malleus
  • Grade 3 – Limited outer attic wall erosion
  • Grade 4 – Severe outer attic wall erosion

questions.text:
Which of the following categories are included under the Modified Robson classification :
  1. Onset of labor
  2. Gestational age
  3. Maternal Age 
  4. Fetal presentation
  5. Presence of DM and/ or Hypertension
questions.solution:
Under the modified Robson system classification gestational age, fetal presentation, and onset of labor are included. The additional categories include parity and number of fetuses.

It is the most widely accepted classification system available for analysing characteristics of delivering women worldwide. It consists of 10 patient population categories. The basis for these categories are based on the following Obstetric variables

  • Parity
    • Nullipara
    • Multipara
  •  Previous CS 
    • Yes (one or more)
    • No
  • Onset of labor
    • Spontaneous
    • Induced
    • No labour (pre-labour CS)
  • Number of fetuses
    • Singleton
    • Multiple
  • Gestational age 
    • Preterm (less than 37 weeks)
    • Term (37 weeks or more)
  • Fetal lie and presentation
    • Cephalic presentation
    • Breech presentation
    • Transverse lie

The modified Robson system classification is as follows:

Class 1 Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor
Class 2 Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, induced labor or CS before labor i. 2a: induced labor ii. 2b: CS before labor
Class 3 Multipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor (excludes previous CS)
Class 4 Multipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, induced or CS before labor (excludes previous CS) i. 4a: induced labor ii. 4b: CS before labor
Class 5 Multipara, previous CS, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic
Class 6 Nullipara, single, breech
Class 7 Multipara, single, breech (including previous CS)
Class 8 Multiple pregnancies (with or without previous CS)
Class 9 Singleton pregnancy, oblique/transverse lie (with or without previous CS)
Class 10  Single, cephalic <37 weeks (including previous CS)

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fractures in ascending order of their severity as per the Gustilo-Anderson classification for open fractures.
  1. A 16 cm open wound with comminuted fractures but intact soft tissue coverage
  2. A 14 cm open wound with comminuted fractures that require concomitant soft tissue reconstructive surgery
  3. A 11 cm open wound with comminuted fracture and arterial injury requiring vascular repair
  4. A 6 cm open wound with a moderately comminuted fracture and some muscle damage.
questions.solution:
As per Gustilo and Anderson's classification, the respective grades are

A 16 cm open wound with comminuted fractures but intact soft tissue coverage - IIIA
A 14 cm open wound with comminuted fractures that require concomitant soft tissue reconstructive surgery - IIIB
A 11 cm open wound with comminuted fracture and arterial injury requiring vascular repair - IIIC
A 6 cm open wound with a moderately comminuted fracture and some muscle damage - II

Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures. An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

questions.text: Masaoka staging system is used for which tumor?
questions.solution:
Masaoka staging system is used for staging thymoma. It is based on the presence or absence of metastasis and gross or microscopic invasion of the capsule and surrounding structures. 

Masaoka staging system for thymoma:

Stage

Features

Stage I

Encapsulated tumor with no gross or microscopic evidence of capsular invasion

Stage II

Gross capsular invasion or invasion into the mediastinal fat or pleura or microscopic capsular invasion

Stage III

Gross invasion into the pericardium, great vessels, or lung

Stage IVA

Pleural or pericardial dissemination

Stage IVB

Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis

Management of Thymoma:

Stage I - complete surgical excision only

Stage II & III - complete surgical excision followed by radiotherapy

Stage IV & metastatic disease - neoadjuvant chemotherapy + surgery + postoperative radiotherapy

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus.  What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain. 

Sarnat staging of HIE:

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress it; otherwise, can remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures. 

 Poor prognostic factors in HIE are:

  • Initial blood ph less than 6.7
  • Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score
  • Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing
  • Seizure onset in less than 12 hours
  • Burst suppression pattern in EEG
  • Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion
  • Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours
  • Decerebrate posture

questions.text: According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, which type of nerve fiber carries proprioceptive signals?
questions.solution:
According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, proprioception is carried by Aα fiber.

Erlanger and Gasser classified nerve fibers into types A, B, and C, with type A fibers further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

  • Type A fibers are the typical large- and medium-­sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.
  • Type B fibers are smaller fibers with minimal myelination. They transmit impulses of the ANS, including the bladder. (B for Bladder)
  • Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient was diagnosed with varicose veins a few months back. He now comes to the outpatient clinic with the finding shown in the image. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?

CEAP- Clinical etiology anatomy pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders.
questions.solution:
The given image in a patient with a known case of varicose veins is atrophie blanche. It is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Corona phlebectatica is the presence of abnormally visible cutaneous blood vessels. Lipodermatosclerosis is a chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, that appears as a ‘woody’ leg on examination.

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).
